text: all right this is our site these are our
rain protection here we got an extension
cord going down to the house there we
set up our weather station over here a
sound meter right here and we'll just go
about doing doing the business here
several times a week art Lindgren
trudges into the darkness near his home
to measure the sound of three nearby
wind turbines this has to be facing
north
mr. Lindgren and his wife Cheryl live on
the island of Vinalhaven off the coast
of Maine the turbines were built by the
Fox Islands Electric Cooperative which
is largely owned and funded by the
thirteen hundred or so full and
part-time residents here we took a vote
and the vote turned out to be about I
think I think the results are about
three hundred eighty four to four in
favor of building the project the
turbines began running last November
and that say a group of Island residents
is when the problems started mean the
first ten minutes we're just our jaws
dropped to the to the ground we were
nobody in in the area could believe they
were so loud they wake us up at night
they're hard to go to sleep too since
then the turbines have become the center
of a bitter controversy that has rattled
this island community and raised
questions about the social costs of
renewable sources of energy like wind we
built this house in 2000 it's a project
that we've waited our whole life to do
we're retired and this is this is it
we're definitely the victims in this
case in that we just happen to live near
the turbines David and Sally Wiley
bought property here in 1992 their home
is about a half mile from where the
turbines spin we were supportive of the
project we were just moving along with
our lives we were told it wasn't going
to be noisy the way this has been
handled to date has been to really
marginalize us and to divide the
community but for others on this rocky
island known widely for its fresh
Lobster and tranquil living the wind
project has become a genuine source of
pride I think they look nice and I think
the majority of us like them the
majority of us are happy with them
the turbines are expected to produce
over 11,000 megawatt hours of
electricity per year a little more than
what is needed by Vinalhaven and nearby
North Haven Island the remainder is sold
to the mainland they've brought my light
bill down a lot it's they used to run
around that 180 or so in in March it
went down to 113 critics on the islands
say their electric bills might have
dropped even without the turbines but
the controversy here is emblematic of
the challenges that the wind industry
increasingly faces as turbines are built
nearby where people live in some cases
sound is a problem in others the impact
is visual some environmentalists also
say turbines can have an impact on
wildlife and here like elsewhere people
have different opinions about the
inherent trade-off
I mean what makes a difference if it's
going like that all day long but just
can think good
the co-operative says that Islanders
were informed of the potential for noise
which they said would not exceed the
state's nighttime limit of 45 decibels
we had a lot of discussions about what
the sound would be like I think we did
an extremely thorough job in educating
people as to what this project was going
to be like if you managed to stay the
night out here and you are lucky enough
to be woken up by these things at 2:00
in the morning you'll hear exactly what
we're talking about this is the audio
recorder but Mr Lindgren who has been
taking his own measurements says the
turbines regularly exceed the legal
limit I would say there is about as
close as we're gonna get tonight 247 in
July mr. Lungren sent his results to the
Maine Department of Environmental
Protection an acoustic consultant hired
by the agency said in September that the
turbines indeed exceeded the state's
nighttime noise standards the operators
of the wind farm are contesting those
results but they say they will abide by
the final ruling the ultimate finding is
that we are above any of the limitations
that will will operate them at a lower
lower mode
it's not greenhouse gases and
save-the-world and in global warming
that's not what we're dealing with here
part of your plan has to be well what
are we going to do with the people that
it puts out it puts ruins their lives
